awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Controlling Wax-Water Interactions in Pores of Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a chemical reaction that converts carbon monoxide and hydrogen into water, carbon dioxide, and hydrocarbons.  This reaction is a critical and commercially relevant process for upgrading feedstocks such as natural gas (including shale gas resources), coal, and even biomass into useful chemicals and fuels.  FTS is catalyzed by metal catalysts (e.g., iron, cobalt or ruthenium) and occurs within very small pores of inexpensive oxide supports (e.g., silica, alumina or titanium dioxide). This research project aims to unravel longstanding mysteries concerning the role of water in FTS catalysis and to leverage those discoveries to create new materials that can lead to more efficient and selective FTS catalysts.   The outcomes of this research project will lead to improvements in converting natural gas, coal, and biomass into liquid fuels and chemicals. Furthermore, this project will leverage programs at the University of Florida and Ohio State University to support the involvement of K-12 and undergraduate students, with a focus on under-represented groups, in this research. 

The water formed during FTS has been shown to increase the rates of FTS as well as shift selectivities towards more desirable long-chain hydrocarbons. However, these promotional effects are not universal, as some studies have shown that water either has a minor impact on FTS rates or causes them to decrease. The effects of water depend on the pore size and hydrophilicity of the oxide support being used in a manner that suggests that water may condense within the pores of the support. These pores are filled with hydrophobic liquid hydrocarbons during FTS, and this hydrophobic environment may assist in capillary condensation of water by effectively reducing the pore size of the support.  The first objective of this research project is to determine whether water is condensed within the pores of ruthenium-based FTS catalysts under industrially-relevant conditions by synthesizing and testing Ru catalysts on SBA-15 silica supports.  Organosilane surface modifiers will be used to alter the pore size and hydrophobicity of the support.  The second objective is to clarify the mechanistic role of water on carbon-oxygen bond activation and carbon-carbon bond formation pathways relevant to the rate and selectivity of FTS.  DFT calculations will be performed to study water-assisted reaction pathways with and without extended water solvation networks. The results of this research project will provide additional evidence for the role of water during catalysis and determine whether the influence of water on reaction rates and mechanism requires condensed water phases or simply water vapor. The discovery that water is condensed within the pores of FTS catalysts at industrially-relevant conditions would provide a shift in our understanding of FTS and would have the potential to create new strategies for improving FTS catalyst reactivity, selectivity, and stability.

por.por_cntn:
Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a critical and commercially relevant process for upgrading CO-H2 feedstocks—formed from as natural gas (including shale gas resources), coal, and biomass—into useful chemicals and fuels. Water is a byproduct of FTS and has been shown to increase FTS reaction rates and to shift the hydrocarbon product distribution towards desired long-chain molecules. Prior studies have shown that the effects of water on FTS rates depends on catalyst properties, such as the active metal (Co or Ru) material as well as the hydrophilicity of the oxide support (typically SiO2 or Al2O3) and the pore-size distribution of the oxide support. Catalysts supported in small-pore supports have rates that are less sensitive to water pressure, while catalysts supported in large-pore supports have rates that increase with increasing water pressure. Prior studies of the effects of water on FTS rates and selectivities focused on typical conditions and on amorphous SiO2 and Al2O3 support materials.

The interplay between the effects of water and the properties of the oxide support have led to proposals that water vapor undergoes capillary condensation to form liquid water within the oxide pores at the high partial pressures present during FTS, despite operating temperatures being well above the normal boiling point. Capillary condensation is a well-known phenomenon in oxide materials, and the conditions at which water undergoes capillary condensation can be measured on oxide materials. However, during FTS reactions the oxide pores are filled with liquid hydrocarbon products (waxes) that diffuse slowly and effectively reduce oxide pore size and the conditions where capillary condensation will occur, complicating the situation. This project aimed to manipulate the oxide pore environment by changing the size of the pores as well as the presence (or absence) of waxy materials produced by FTS to gain insights into the role of water during FTS, whether it is condensed within pores, and the interplay between water-pores-wax that dictates performance.

In this project, we measured the effects of water during CO-H2 reactions on Ru catalysts supported in both amorphous SiO2 and in well-ordered SBA-15 SiO2 materials. These well-ordered SBA-15 materials have narrow pore-size distributions when carefully synthesized and their pore sizes can be varied over a narrow range (~5–12 nm in diameter). Furthermore, we examined the effects of water at three sets of conditions, one typical of FTS synthesis (483 K, 0.5 MPa CO, 2.3 MPa H2), one that produces more methane and less long-chain hydrocarbons (‘low-wax’: 513 K, 0.03 MPa CO, 0.4 MPa H2), and one that produces >70% methane (‘wax-free’: 523 K, 0.03 MPa CO, 0.4 MPa H2) and very little waxy (long-chain) products. These varied conditions were chosen to alter the amount of intrapore liquid hydrocarbons (wax) present during reaction.

Reactions were run on high-pressure reaction units with several weeks of time-on-stream to resemble practical operation of FTS catalysts and minimize artifacts associated with catalyst deactivation. The effects of water pressure were sensitive to the nature of the support, as shown in prior work, with 5 wt. % Ru in wide-pore (10–15 nm) amorphous SiO2 supports being having FTS rates more sensitive to water pressure than when they are supported in 10 nm well-ordered SBA-15 SiO2 supports.

As hypothesized, water effects were also sensitive to the presence (or absence) of liquid hydrocarbon products. Reactions at FTS and ‘low-wax’ conditions showed nearly identical effects of water, rates increase by a factor of ~2 with increasing water pressure, reaching a saturation behavior at water pressures above 0.5 MPa H2O, and this is also consistent with prior FTS studies. At ‘wax-free’ conditions, however,  rates decreased with increasing water pressure, with rates decreasing sharply near 0.1 MPa H2O, indicating irreversible deactivation at those conditions. This suggests that the liquid hydrocarbons formed during FTS protect the catalyst against water-induced deactivation by metal sintering.

SBA-15 synthesis efforts for this project established the importance of eliminating micropore regions that connect the desired mesopores as well as method for micropore elimination. Pore-size control was established over a wide range (4.5 – 12 nm) in these micropore-free SBA-15 materials. SBA-15 materials were also grafted with alkylsilane and aminosilane ligands and N2 physisorption characterizations revealed that this grafting operation also eliminated micropore regions. Probe reactions using aldols and nitroaldols were examined to assess the potential of these SBA-15 materials as bifunctional catalysts.

This project yielded valuable insights into the role of water and wax in pores of FTS catalysts, and developed new synthesis methods for forming SBA-15 materials with narrow and variable pore-size distributions as well as bifunctionality through grafted ligands. Further, graduate and undergraduate students were educated in fundamentals of catalyst synthesis, characterization, and reactivity measurements.
